title: Upper Limb Nerve Lesions — Patterns & Pearls
summary: From distal to proximal: recognize patterns of radial, median, and ulnar nerve lesions and link hallmark motor/sensory findings to lesion level.
high_yield: Radial nerve distal lesion → wrist drop + dorsum hand sensory loss (digits 1–3).
Superficial radial branch injury at dorsum wrist is sensory-only.
AIN syndrome → failed 'OK' sign (FPL + lateral FDP).
Ulnar elbow lesion → radial deviation on wrist flexion (FCU denervated).
pitfalls: Don't overfit to named syndromes; anchor on motor units and cutaneous map.
'Hand of Benediction' test requires making a fist (proximal median lesion).

content.text: Distal radial nerve compression produces loss of wrist/digit extension (wrist drop) and sensory loss over the lateral dorsum of the hand. Proximal/axillary lesions add loss of elbow extension and expand sensory deficits.

content.caption: Wrist drop with radial nerve palsy.

content.stem: A patient with compression of the radial nerve in the distal arm presents with difficulty using the hand. Which primary motor deficit do you expect?

choices.text: Inability to extend the wrist and digits (wrist drop)
Inability to flex the DIP of the index finger

rationale.correct: Radial nerve innervates wrist/digit extensors; distal compression classically produces wrist drop.

distractors.A: Median (recurrent motor) to thenar muscles handles opposition.
distractors.E: AIN (median) supplies lateral FDP and FPL.

content.title: Focus on maps
content.body: Know which skin territory and which muscle groups map to each nerve; memorize patterns, not syndromes.
